info.game_comments:
WE ASKED: Actor Josh Gad.
A poorly-worded Final Jeopardy! clue disadvantages a challenger, resulting in her being brought back later in the week.
Alex uses a cane during the closing credits chat.

(1, 1).clue: "Good Times" & "The Good Wife": very different parts of this city

(2, 1).clue: To organize papers, or to administer to one's ragged nails

(3, 1).clue: The website for this company, jnj.com, lists products like Head-To-Toe Fragrance Free Baby Lotion

(4, 1).clue: This mechanical device is used by musicians to keep time

(5, 1).clue: Greeks thought foreigners talking sounded like "Bar-bar-bar", maybe the origin of this word for uncivilized people

(2, 2).clue: To heat & sweeten a beverage with spice

(3, 2).clue: It's last alphabetically on the Dow & first numerically on the Fortune 500

(4, 2).clue: A popular folk instrument in Latin America, this variety of xylophone originated in Africa

(5, 2).clue: Cleveland Browns fans aren't fans of this team that has won 6 Super Bowls

(1, 3).clue: "Frasier" & the American remake of "The Killing": this city, in very different moods

(3, 3).clue: This Dow Jones-listed company offered its own version of a Daily Double, as well as "world famous fries"

(4, 3).clue: Type of Renaissance vocal work for multiple voices heard here

(5, 3).clue: In experiments, good people can be taught to dehumanize others, an effect named for this angel gone bad

(6, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows a video on the monitor.) A fighter pilot who takes a defensive position behind and to one side of a squadron mate is called this, whether in combat or a singles bar

(1, 4).clue: "Little House on the Prairie" & "The Mary Tyler Moore Show": this state

(2, 4).clue: To thin the herd by removing inferior stock

(4, 4).clue: In 1826 at just 17 he produced the dazzling "Midsummer Night's Dream" overture

(5, 4).clue: A colonial-era stereotype of Native Americans as uncorrupted is called this type of "savage"

(6, 4).clue: The USS Mitscher & USS Preble are this type of fast, maneuverable warship; sadly, there's no USS Conan

(1, 5).clue: "Cold Case" & "thirtysomething": this city called an elegant but jaded lady

(2, 5).clue: To ward off blows, or to take care of oneself

(4, 5).clue: This elegant dance for couples dominated aristocratic European ballrooms from about 1650 to 1750

(5, 5).clue: In a 2012 interview Stephen Hawking, who can easily understand quantum gravity, said these are "a complete mystery"

(6, 5).clue: In WWI & again in WWII, the Allies countered U-boat threats by sailing in these groups, from a word meaning "escort"

(1, 1).clue: Sparking a bloody backlash, Yamassee Indians massacred South Carolina colonists on this day, 2 before Easter

(2, 1).clue: As this "Aladdin" character, Robin Williams did impressions of Groucho Marx, Schwarzenegger & others

(4, 1).clue: This neighbor is Zimbabwe's leading trade partner, accounting for more than 30% of exports & 40% of imports

(5, 1).clue: In 1703 this "Robinson Crusoe" author offended each side in a religious dispute & was sentenced to Newgate Prison

(6, 1).clue: An old joke: this outermost layer of skin "is showing!"

(2, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Josh Gad.) In 2014 I won an Annie award-- excellence in animation-- for my work voicing this adorable character in "Frozen"

(4, 2).clue: A region called the Great Dyke holds vast riches of this silvery precious metal, atomic number 78

(5, 2).clue: Although best known for their fairy tales, these brothers were pioneers in creating a German dictionary

(6, 2).clue: It's from the Greek for "upon a tomb"

(1, 3).clue: In 1715 this country waged war against Russia, Poland & Denmark in the Baltics

(2, 3).clue: This sultry bombshell from a 1988 hit claimed, "I'm not bad. I'm just drawn that way"

(3, 3).clue: She was awarded the National Medal of Arts in 1990, the same year as her husband Hume Cronyn

(4, 3).clue: In 1987 he became the country's first president; Zimbabweans are still waiting for the second one

(5, 3).clue: "The Girl in the Spider's Web" continues the late Stieg Larsson's "Millennium series" about this hacker

(6, 3).clue: 9-letter word meaning pertaining to a bishop

(1, 4).clue: The Jacobite rebellion tried to put a member of this royal family back on the English throne but failed

(2, 4).clue: This funny bunny in "Bambi" teaches Bambi how to slide on ice & talk

(3, 4).clue: "It Happened One Night" in 1986 that this film director was awarded his medal

(5, 4).clue: Tolstoy titled a story after these horsemen of the steppes, based on his travels as a soldier

(1, 5).clue: France's Louis XV became king at age 5 with his relative Philippe, the duc of this city, serving as regent

(2, 5).clue: This acorn-obsessed squirrel is always in search of the elusive nut in the "Ice Age" films

(3, 5).clue: This 1996 honoree won 3 Pulitzers for his plays, the first for "A Delicate Balance" in 1967

(4, 5).clue: In 2015 Zimbabweans & the world mourned this beloved 13-year-old lion, killed for sport

(5, 5).clue: Richard Llewellyn wrote 3 sequels to this 1939 classic; in the third one, Huw Morgan returns to Wales

(0, 0).clue: The first woman space shuttle pilot shares this surname with a man on the 1st manned lunar landing 26 years earlier
